(This comment applies to other Tasks, too)

This task has no state and is internal to MapLibre, i.e. potentially does not interface with Java code. The idiomatic Kotlin way for this would look like this, i.e. not a class but a suspending function)

```suggestion
suspend fun requestLocalUrl(url: String): ByteArray? = withContext(IO) {
   loadFile(...)
}
```

The current approach causes a leak of the coroutine scope because the `LocalRequestTask` is not garbage collected as long as the owner of `LocalRequestTask` is not. No idea how serious it is, my guess would be: not at all, but ðŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸ - it is quite similar to the problem with `AsyncTask`, i.e. why that class was deprecated.

Now, it seems like (currently) it does interface with Java code (`NativeHttpRequest.java`). Actually, not sure how suspending functions look like from Java-code, but according to [stackoverflow answers](https://www.google.de/search?q=suspend+functions+in+java+code+site:stackoverflow.com&sca_esv=1c866aa5bb9857de&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjfmfm5-eKHAxVEwAIHHUW7F40QrQIoBHoECCMQBQ&biw=2048&bih=999&dpr=1.25), one can wrap it quite easily in a Java `CompletableFuture`.

discussion_comments.comment_body:
So, it looks like there is no easy way to interface suspending code to Android Java API 21+. 

Only when the code that uses this has also been migrated to Kotlin it could be made more Kotlin-idiomatic.

`launch` returns a `Job`. You could also return it in `execute`.

In any case, (separate issue), here you cancel the `SupervisorJob`, i.e. the parent job. After the `SupervisorJob` is cancelled, IIRC no new jobs can be launched in that job. IIRC subsequent calls to `execute` would then just immediately cancel. (But I didn't test this, maybe it would throw an IllegalStateException when trying to launch a new job in a cancelled supervisor job?)
That would be fine if the `BitmapImageConversionTask` is a single-use object, but then, why does it need a `SupervisorJob`? In any case, needs documentation.

The `execute` call could potentially be launched several times.  The intent was that the `SupervisorJob` would cancel all of them.  Note that `BitmapImageConversionTask.cancel` is only called when the `Style` is cleared.

I'll add a comment to clarify that.

Hmm, this reads a bit odd. I have to look up what it does... this is a global coroutine scope, right?

I.e. it runs app-wide, independent of any e.g. view lifecycle. Is this what you want to do? Because, like other Tasks, this one has a callback. So, the callback is fired no matter what, even if the listener should have been removed already (out of lifecycle).

(As for the other tasks, the Kotlin-idiomatic way would be to have this as a suspend function, i.e.
```kotlin
suspend fun getResourcesCachePath(context: Context): String = 
    withContext(IO) { FileSource.getCachePath(context) }
```
